channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Before Elections, Mumbai Snack Turns Into a Political Hot Potato
item.description: The Shiv Sena, the Hindu nationalist party that dominates the city’s government, is quietly helping voters set up stalls to sell the street food vada pav in return for their support.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI
item.media:description: A stall affiliated with the Shiv Sena party selling vada pav, a popular snack in Mumbai.

item.title: World Briefing: Nepal: Push to Open Peaks to Climbers
item.description: The government is considering contracts with climbing companies that would grant exclusive access to many of its highest mountains, a spokesman for Nepal’s tourism ministry said on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: World Briefing: El Salvador: Demonstrators Blocked at Count of Vote in Presidential Runoff
item.description: The police blocked hundreds of supporters of the conservative candidate in El Salvador’s presidential election from reaching a hotel where the authorities were doing a final count Monday for the runoff contest.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Suit Filed in Haiti Cholera Epidemic
item.description: A class-action lawsuit claiming to represent cholera victims in Haiti and their relatives in the United States was filed against the United Nations on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Guilty Verdicts in Rendition Case
item.description: The country’s highest court upheld guilty verdicts against the three United States defendants in the 2003 extraordinary rendition kidnapping of Osama Moustafa Hassan Nasr.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Gaza: Explosives in a House Kill 3
item.description: An explosion on Tuesday at a house in Beit Hanoun, a town in the northern Gaza Strip, killed three people and wounded at least seven others, the Gaza Ministry of Health said.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Cancale Journal: In France, a Quest to Convert a Sea Snail Plague Into a Culinary Pleasure
item.description: The community of Cancale now finds itself torn between disgust and relief at an entrepreneur’s project to fish and sell the sea snails for consumption.
item.dc:creator: By LALITA CLOZEL
item.media:credit: Catalina Martin-Chico for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean-François Dore raked up the Atlantic slipper shells that cover the seabed in the waters off Cancale in France in an attempt to protect the area’s oyster and mussel farms from the invasive sea snails.

item.title: Wanted by Ecuador, 2 Brothers Make Mark in U.S. Campaigns
item.description: Donations in two fugitives’ case creates the appearance of a conflict of interest for the Obama administration, which has rejected Ecuador’s extradition request for the men.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roberto Isaias, who has withstood extradition requests from Ecuador, in Miami last month.

item.title: News Analysis: China Torn Between Policies and Partnership
item.description: China is struggling to find a neutral diplomatic position over Russia’s intervention in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Obama Team Debates How to Punish Russia
item.description: As President Obama searches for a way to contain and ultimately reverse Russia’s invasion of southern Ukraine without using force, his team finds itself torn over just how far to go using economic weapons.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk of Ukraine will visit the White House on Wednesday for a show of solidarity.

item.title: Libya’s Prime Minister Ousted in Chaos Over Tanker
item.description: The ouster of Prime Minister Ali Zeidan underscored the explosive danger of loss of control over Libya’s petroleum, the lifeblood of its economy.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Death of Boy Caught in Melee Spurs Protests Across Turkey
item.description: News of his death triggered large gatherings in several cities, including Istanbul, Izmir and Ankara, where the police confronted protesters with tear gas and water cannons.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Political Killings Still Plaguing Post-Qaddafi Libya
item.description: Political divisions within the elected General National Congress, with groups backed by rival militias, have rendered the appointed government almost powerless.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: People opposing an extension of the national government’s powers blocked a main street in the eastern Libyan city of Benghazi last month.

item.title: Stolen Passports on Plane Not Seen as Terror Link
item.description: Interpol said that two passengers known to have used stolen passports to board the Malaysia Airlines jet that vanished were unlikely to be linked to terrorist groups.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The authorities released photographs of two Iranians who boarded the Malaysia Airlines flight with false documents: Pouria Nourmohammadi Mehrdad, left, and another man, identified by Interpol as Delavar Seyed Mohammad Reza.

item.title: Fears Spread That Venezuela Is Approaching Bloody Face-Off
item.description: People on both sides of the country’s political divide seem increasingly willing to accept violence.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Conflict Erupts in Public Rebuke on C.I.A. Inquiry
item.description: Senator Dianne Feinstein, the chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said the C.I.A. searched computers being used by committee staff members to investigate the agency’s interrogation tactics.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Senator Dianne Feinstein, the chairwoman of the Senate intelligence committee.

item.title: U.N. Denies That Syria Image Was Faked
item.description: A photograph of hungry Palestinians in Syria, retweeted more than eight million times, has become an iconic image of the war. Experts said it was real.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: This photo of Palestinian refugees lining up for food aid in Syria has drawn wide attention online.

item.title: At Trial of Bin Laden Relative, Witness Describes Meeting 9/11 Mastermind
item.description: An operative for Al Qaeda offered an intimate account of his interactions with Osama bin Laden and Khalid Shaikh Mohammed in the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:credit: Al-Jazeera, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: The Lede: U.N. Denies Altering Image of Palestinian Refugees in Damascus
item.description: A United Nations spokesman rejected claims that an arresting image of thousands of Palestinian refugees waiting for food distribution on a ruined street in Damascus recently had been digitally altered.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A photograph of food distribution in a Damascus refugee camp for Palestinians released by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency in January.

item.title: Air Links Are Severed as Russia Tightens Its Grip on Crimean Peninsula
item.description: Declaring that he remained commander in chief, Viktor F. Yanukovych denounced the West for rushing to recognize the interim authorities and to provide financial assistance.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: People in Sevastopol watched the televised speech of former Ukrainian president Viktor F. Yanukovych on Tuesday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Ukraine’s President Rebuffs Russian ‘Imperialism’
item.description: Ukrainians want peace, but we will not submit to Soviet-style bullying.
item.dc:creator: By OLEKSANDR V TURCHYNOV

item.title: N.S.A. Nominee Promotes Cyberwar Units
item.description: Citing cyberattacks on the new Ukrainian government, President Obama’s nominee to run the National Security Agency, Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, said “cyber will be an element of every crisis.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Letter from Europe: Seeing a Threat at Home in a Fight Abroad
item.description: To what extent do Europeans joining the fight in Syria risk coming home with the intent to support or participate in acts of terrorism?
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: With $21 Billion Loss, Italian Bank Signals Wider Vulnerabilities
item.description: The lender says its holdings are far less valuable than thought, as the European Central Bank plans to scrutinize the books of euro zone banks.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: UniCredit's headquarters in Milan. The bank reported a fourth-quarter loss of 15 billion euros, or about $21 billion.

item.title: Western Journalist Is Shot and Killed as Kabul Mourns Official’s Death
item.description: The attack on a Swedish reporter was the first time in years that a foreigner appeared to have been specifically targeted and killed in Kabul.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
